author: timbeiko
content: +1, I think preserving "length compatibility" will probably prevent tooling from breaking in weird ways

author: sky.cactus
content: What do you mean by length compatibility?

author: .vbuterin
content: Like making new-style addresses also 42 chars, so tools that expect that length don't have to update

author: sky.cactus
content: I *suspect* that any tool that checks length also probably checks characters (e.g., `0x[a-zA-Z0-9]{40}` regexp).

author: peter.davies
content: I also suggest a human readable prefix that identifies the chain (e.g. "eth"), so that people can't accidentally send things to Ethereum addresses on other chains like BSC.

author: pipermerriam
content: I'm confused, I thought that we were shooting for 32-byte addresses.  Is this suggesting an encoding that targets 42 characters to stay inline with how long 20-byte addresses are in the `0x` hex format?  This seems like the opposite of what I would expect since we would want a clear way to differentiate between new/old.  Keeping them the same length seems to suggest some level of ambiguity in parsing.

author: peter.davies
content: Most of the major security risks from Address Space Extension come from various permutations of attempting to use a long address as a legacy one. We should probably try to actively break anything that processes addresses as anything more than an opaque string.

author: peter.davies
content: I suspect anyone who is storing an address in a fixed length buffer is parsing it to binary format first and will just have to update.

author: timbeiko
content: Fair enough, that makes sense! Not a very strong opinion on my end
